page.title: 02PETROCKSTOWE'S LANDSCAPE
page.content: {Petrockstowe}is an attractive hilly area, with many thatched cottages made of cob or Devon stone, adjacent to metalled roads, but often tucked away down partially-surfaced tracks, hidden by Devon banks, surrounded by{grazing {land}filled with sheep or cows. There are plenty of trees - oak, beech, ash, sycamore and conifers - but many of them are ivy-clad and covered with lichen. Roadside hedges and banks are filled with wild daffodils and prim- roses in Spring, the pinks of campion and foxglove in Summer and thick with blackberries, elderberries and hazel- nuts in the Autumn. The field owners are responsible for cutting the roadside hedges. Numerous dry-stone bridges take the lanes over streams which act as natural field boundaries and with many springs provide fresh water for the livestock.
